decisions.title: Internship Offer
decisions.scenario: GlobalFoundries offered you a paid internship: $28/hr for the summer (12 weeks, 40hrs/week). After taxes, you'll make about $9,500. Your friends are backpacking Europe and want you to join ($3,000 for 3 weeks).
decisions.context_info: Early career internships build your resume and can lead to full-time offers. But experiences with friends are also valuable. This is about weighing opportunity cost.

immediate_outcome.text: You committed to the internship. You'll start Monday. Your friends left for Europe without you - FOMO is real.

delayed_consequence.text: You made $9,500 and learned semiconductor manufacturing. GlobalFoundries offered you a part-time position during college ($25/hr, 15hrs/week). Your resume is now competitive for tech jobs.
delayed_consequence.why: Internships open doors. The $9,500 + future job offer + resume boost was worth more than the Europe trip. Your friends' photos made you jealous, but you invested in your future.

immediate_outcome.text: Europe was incredible! You spent $3,000 on the trip. You worked at Panera for the rest of summer ($14/hr). You made about $2,800 in 8 weeks.

delayed_consequence.text: You're applying for summer internships again. Companies asked why you declined GlobalFoundries. You don't have semiconductor experience on your resume. Most positions are already filled by students who interned last summer.
delayed_consequence.why: Declining a strong internship has costs beyond just the money. In competitive fields, early experience compounds. Europe was fun but didn't build your career capital.

decisions.title: 401k Enrollment
decisions.scenario: GlobalFoundries offers full-time after graduation: $65,000/year. During orientation, they explained the 401k: you can contribute up to 6% of salary, they'll match 100%. That's free money. But 6% is $325/month you won't see in your paycheck.
decisions.context_info: Employer 401k match is the best investment deal you'll ever get - it's an instant 100% return. But it's locked until retirement (age 59¬Ω), and many young people skip it to have more cash now.

immediate_outcome.text: You enrolled at 6%. Your paycheck will be $325/month less, but GlobalFoundries adds $325/month to your 401k. Your take-home is still $4,092/month.

delayed_consequence.text: Your 401k has $53,000. You contributed $23,400 over 6 years. GlobalFoundries contributed $23,400 (the match). Investment growth added $6,200. You got $29,600 in free money by saying yes at 19.
delayed_consequence.why: Starting retirement savings at 19 instead of 25 means 6 extra years of compound growth. The match is free money you can never get back if you skip it. Your 25-year-old self is very grateful.

immediate_outcome.text: You declined the 401k. Your full paycheck is $4,417/month. You'll figure out retirement later - you're only 19.

delayed_consequence.text: You finally enrolled in the 401k at 25. You have $0 saved. Your friends who started at 19 have $50,000+. You left $23,400 in free matching money on the table. You can never get those years back.
delayed_consequence.why: Skipping the 401k match is leaving free money on the table. The extra $325/month in your paycheck was spent on things you don't remember. Starting 6 years late costs you hundreds of thousands by retirement age.

decisions.title: Car Purchase
decisions.scenario: Your 2008 Honda died. You need a car for work. Options: (1) Used Toyota Camry 2018, $18,000, reliable, 5% loan. (2) New Tesla Model 3, $45,000, 7% loan, your dream car. (3) Cheaper used car $8,000, might need repairs.
decisions.context_info: Cars depreciate fast. New cars lose 20% value when you drive off the lot. A $45k car on a $65k salary means high payments that limit other financial goals.

immediate_outcome.text: You financed $18,000 at 5% for 5 years. Your payment is $340/month. The car is clean, reliable, and has 45,000 miles. Not exciting but smart.

delayed_consequence.text: Your Camry has 90,000 miles and runs perfectly. You paid it off (total paid: $20,400). It's worth $12,000. Total cost of ownership: $8,400. You saved the difference and have $15,000 for a house down payment.
delayed_consequence.why: Reliable used cars are the financial sweet spot. You avoided new car depreciation, kept payments reasonable, and freed up money for wealth-building goals.

immediate_outcome.text: You financed $45,000 at 7% for 6 years. Your payment is $767/month. The car is incredible - tech, performance, looks. You feel successful.

delayed_consequence.text: You've paid $36,816 so far and still owe $15,000. The car is worth $22,000. You're underwater on the loan. Your friends are buying houses - you can't afford a down payment because $767/month for 4 years ate your savings ability.
delayed_consequence.why: Cars are tools, not investments. Spending 70% of your annual salary on a car meant you couldn't save for wealth-building. The $767/month difference could have been $36,816 toward a house.
